Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Probing the Beta-amyloidogenic Structure and Function of Hemolysin A From Proteus Mirabilis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most interesting questions in biology today is the process by which properly folded proteins convert into insoluble helix amyloid fibrils. A hallmark feature of amyloid fibril formation is that a template-assisted model in which the surface of a mis-folded protein activates the mis-folding of nearby folded proteins. Currently, two different types of protein surfaces have been used during template-assisted amyloid fibril formation: (1) a cross beta interface and (2) an extended fibril-like interface. Hemolysin A (HpmA), a hemolytic toxin from Proteus mirabilis, will be used as a model to investigate the role of surface activation during a template-assisted hemolysis assay. HpmA belongs to the energy independent two-partner secretion (TPS) pathway, exhibits template-assisted activity, harbors a helix rich monomeric structure and forms oligomers in cross-beta and extended fibril conformations. Therefore, it serves as a good model to investigate surface interactions with regard to protein folding. Specific goals of this research are to test the hypothesis that either the cross-beta or fibril-like oligomeric surfaces within HpmA are utilized during the template-assisted activation of hemolysis. A series of site-directed mutants will be engineered based upon data from the recently solved x-ray structure for a truncated form of HpmA. These mutants will be designed to disrupt either the cross beta or fibril-like surfaces. Once generated, each mutant form of HpmA will be analyzed for template-assisted activity within a hemolysis assay. These studies will provide new structural and functional information regarding the role of surface activation within TPS pathways, the most commonly used protein secretion pathway in nature. In many aspects, HpmA structurally and functionally mimics amyloid type proteins. Therefore, the results from these studies may assist the understanding of how protein surfaces are used during template-assisted amyloid fibril formation.

Broader Impact: The most important impact of the project is that it will be conducted at a primarily undergraduate institution with involvement of undergraduate students as one of the primary missions. It will further enhance the undergraduate research culture at the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse. Undergraduate students involved in the project will gain valuable research skills, learn new techniques, and collect and present their results both locally and nationally. In addition, the project has a K-12 outreach component in which a high school science educator will become familiar with the research project, develop new techniques and integrate these into her classroom. The high school students will benefit by applying these learned techniques toward an actual research project, which should strengthen their interest in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins conduct a number of beneficial cellular functions including digestion, sensory perception, movement, immune defense, and energy production. However, proteins can also act through nefarious means during bacterial infection and neurodegenerative disease (NDD). Invasive bacterial organisms typically harbor protein-derived virulence factors. As an ensemble, these factors provide the bacteria with a means to attach, invade, and damage host cells during the infection process. Bacterial species, including those that are causative agents of whooping cough, food-borne illness, meningitis, and plague, utilize a number of proteins-based virulence factors. Additionally, some progressive NDDs are typified by the presence of deleterious protein molecules termed beta-amyloid (betaA). These betaA withhold unique properties and facilitate atypical processes, like beta-helix structures and self-propagation. Simply, one betaA protein can act as a template and interconvert normal surrounding proteins into additional betaA proteins. Systematic production of betaA proteins in this fashion has been termed template-assisted activity and lead to collections of insoluble proteins that deposit themselves upon brain tissue. Ultimately, this process leads to progressive neurodegeneration. There are over 20 NDDs linked directly to betaA and the beta-helix protein structure. NDDs can be sub-divided into two classifications: (1) transmissible and (2) non-transmissible. Diseases such as mad cow, chronic wasting (white-tailed deer), kuru (human), Creutzfeldt-Jakob (human) are transmissible forms, while non-transmissible forms include Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.

 

The project utilized hemolysin A, a protein toxin produced by a ubiquitous and energy-independent bacterial secretion system as a model of study. A number of pathogenic bacterial species harboring this particular secretion system target human hosts. Moreover, hemolysin A also withholds the unique betaA type beta-helix structure. Thus, the project focused upon two intellectually and scientifically distinct but equally meritorious areas: (1) pathogenic bacterial infection and (2) neurodegenerative disease. A collection of protein biochemistry, molecular biology, and biophysical techniques were implemented during the characterization of hemolysin A. From these investigations, we have published the three-dimensional structure along with a series of critical functional properties of hemolysin A.

 

The scientific outcomes from this research centered upon the structure-function paradigm of hemolysin A as related to beta-helix structure. The first discovery was the three-dimensional structure of a shortened form of hemolysin A. This right-handed parallel beta-helix structure was shown capped and flanked by sections of anti-parallel beta-sheet. Interestingly, the structure also reported a dimeric species where two individual units of hemolysin A made contact through a hydrophobic and geometrically compatible interface. This sort of protein interface is rather unique and has been proposed as a plausible mode of betaA propagation. Thus, future investigations surrounding this region may provide clues to NDD manifestation. Secondly, a number of functional outcomes were also obtained. Hemolysin A was investigated from a functional perspective and it has demonstrated biphasic, uni-directional, and cooperative template-assisted hemolysis. Again, these functional attributes have been illustrated in betaA type systems during the formation of longer deleterious fibrils. Hopefully, continued structure-function investigations of hemolysin A will provide a model for both bacterial virulence factor and betaA propagation.
